advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> M-SERIES BROCHURE - COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 464 - 6128 PERIPHERALS</strong></font><br><blockquote>From top left to bottom right:<br> - T.V. modulator for the CPC 6128<br> - Joystick with joystick adaptor<br> - T.V. modulator for the CPC 464<br> - Disc drive with interface and CP/M for CPC 464<br> - Speech synthesizer and stereo amplifier<br> - Additional disc drive<br> - Light pen with graphics software<br> - RS232 interface<br> - DMP 2000 dot printer</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CREATIVITY BUILT-IN</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a French advert from december 1985 for a special christmas pack : TO-7/70 + Microsoft Basic level 5 + tape recorder + Colorpaint + Basic initiation cube for "only" 3990 FF. <br><br> "All the world in a present"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROTOTYPE SOFTWARE</strong></font><br><blockquote>This picture from an early advert published in january 1983 is very interesting (the TO-7 was just released then). The text below it said "Hours of entertainment...". But when you look more carefully at the software boxes you realise that they are fake! Only the two extreme boxes are real, but still shows the same game title "3-D TIC-TAC TOE"! So there is only one game presented here! The photograph was surely taken at an early development stage... <br><br> Even the name of the computer written on top of the boxes: "TOM 7" (Tele Ordinateur Multimedia?) seems to be an early name for the TO-7... <br><br> Hours of entertainment they said...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SEMI-TECH BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://club.pep.ne.jp/~p.katsu/pasocata/index.html">P.KATSU</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> STRAPPING MAN!</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> A compact problem-solving add for engineers, statisticians, scientists and financial and business analysts. </font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> VICTOR AD #2 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this advert, the Victor 9000 features was compared with those of four competitor computers: IBM PC, Xerox 820, Apple III and TRS-80 Model II. <br><br> Victor features was definitely higher than all of the desktop computers of the time, including the IBM PC. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>>  U.S. AD #2 (1983) </strong></font><br><blockquote>Despite the M20 was neither software nor hardware compatible with any other computer, Olivetti had to prove that it had more computing power at a smaller pice than any competitor. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> DESKTOP & PORTABLE BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, SEPTEMBER 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICT. #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Larry Greenfield and his <a href="http://www.tcp.com/%7Elgreenf/apfpage.htm" target="_blank">APF Imagination Machine page</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ABORTED ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>One of the aborted advert campaigns for the 8048 was "Micromania".<p class="petitgris">Thomas Fischer</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2 (OCTOBER, 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>''Particuliar sign : painter and musician''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Tim_K for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Computing is very simple with the AIM65 from Rockwell"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1977)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert price list:<br><br> 16K RAM: <b>$399</b> (kit) <b>$459</b> (assembled)<br> Parity option: <b>$39</b> (kit) <b>$59</b> (assembled)<br> Floating point board: <b>$259</b> (kit) <b>$359</b> (assembled)<br> Z80 board: <b>$199</b> (kit) <b>$259</b> (assembled)</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Rui Santos for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> DIABOLIK, FRENCH ADVERT. #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>The YIS-502 was also called the Diabolik in France...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHARLIE CHAPLIN #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>1982 - Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Stop in a store near you. Take a look. You'll be instantly taken with some of the features that make the IBM Personal Computer so different...</font> </blockquote>

computer.description:
As for the PC-88xx series, a lot of versions were released. In 1988, PC-98xx were already sold for hobby users. 8-bit machines were about to become history. The PC-8801FE was positioned as a low-cost entry machine but it did not succeed in the market.
This machine did not have expansion slot, nor N88-BASIC disks (only disk-utilities were included), in order to reduce cost. But it had video-output and superimpose feature to enjoy games on a television. This was the sole new feature.
However, Televisions were already hijacked by Nintendo and RGB monitors were already available for PC-9801. There was no place left for the PC-8801FE.
________
Thanks to Nomura Hisayuki for the info

item.description: Dual 5.25'' floppy discs unit||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> DUAL 5.25'' FLOPPY DISCS UNIT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Dual 5.25" Double-side, double-density 320 KB floppy drive unit. <br> The unit uses the 8255 parallel interface. It can be also used with PC-8001/mkII, PC-8801 Series, PC-9801/E/F/M etc.</blockquote>

computer.keyboard: Full-stroke keyboard with separated numeric keypad
computer.name: PC 8801 FE
computer.ports: Analog RGB video output, Composite video output, Printer, Mouse, Serial interface
